It happened throughout the entire investigation, though not consistent in t=
iming, volume, or rhythm. The only thing consistent was the EMF spikes ever=
ything a tap would occur.

April

  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: t=
hreadsintyme@... 
  To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Wednesday, Ma=
y 27, 2009 5:27 PM
  Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] Electrical Question





  How =
often did it tap? Constantly? Was there any change in either frequency of t=
he taps or anything else?
  Al
  ---------- Original Message ----------
  F=
rom: "April Abercrombie" <april@...>
  To: <EVP-IT=
C@yahoogroups.com>
  Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] Electrical Question [1 Attachme=
nt]
  Date: Wed, 27 May 2009 16:43:21 -0600




  No this was a constant re=
cording. This was caught in an empty room on my camcorder footage, as well =
as on some other recording devices. 

  That coupled with the EMF spikes at=
 the same time confirm that it was in the house, not in the machinery. If i=
t is a static discharge, something is still causing it. But it doesn't soun=
d like a static discharge. I say tap, but it is more of a sharp pop.  I am =
attaching a clip of the sound if you want to hear it.

  This went on const=
antly throughout the entire time we were there, about 4 hours.

    ----- O=
riginal Message ----- 
    From: Rj 
    To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com 
    S=
ent: Tuesday, May 26, 2009 5:30 PM
    Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] Electrical Qu=
estion


          It could: if you've ever noticed the tap sound when star=
ting or stopping a recording session, assuming it is not being caused by pu=
shing a switch in the mic, the tap or pop you hear can be caused by the ele=
ctronics as it begins to ceases recording.

          Also a static charge =
can cause the pop.

          --- On Tue, 5/26/09, April Abercrombie <april=
@...> wrote:


            From: April Abercrombie=
 <april@...>
            Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] El=
ectrical Question
            To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com
            Date:=
 Tuesday, May 26, 2009, 4:15 PM



            Thanks! Would that account f=
or the tapping noise?

              ----- Original Message ----- 
        =
      From: Rj 
              To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
              S=
ent: Tuesday, May 26, 2009 4:07 PM
              Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] Ele=
ctrical Question


                    Yes.  Also faulty wiring, which is e=
ven more dangerous.
                    Also with flakey transformers or ot=
her power distribution in the area, or power lines.
                    Per=
haps you can check with some neighbors, and see how their power is doing.

=

                    --- On Tue, 5/26/09, April Abercrombie <april@abercrom=
biegh ostresearch. com> wrote:


                      From: April Abercrom=
bie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com>
                      Subject: [=
EVP-ITC] Electrical Question
                      To: "EVP-ITC Group" <EVP=
-ITC@yahoogroups .com>
                      Date: Tuesday, May 26, 2009, 2=
:52 PM



                      Hi All,

                      Is there som=
eone here that can answer and electrical question for me?

                =
      During the case that I recorded those possible EVP's-there was a loud=
 tapping noise that seemed to come from the 2nd bedroom. Upon checking my l=
ogs, every time one of  these clicks were heard, there would be an EMF spik=
e in the livingroom. The 2nd bedroom is upstairs, the livingroom downstairs=
. The home owners have also reported that they have a touch lamp that comes=
 on all the time by itself and the lights in the Kitchen will dim occasiona=
lly.

                      Now these taps are not consistent in timing, lo=
udness or rhythm. Could this be the work of faulty breakers?

             =
         Thanks!
                      April 


         






  _________=
